# Kansas City jazz

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Kansas City jazz  
---  
Stylistic origins | [Blues](/wiki/Blues "Blues"), [New Orleans jazz](/wiki/Dixieland "Dixieland"), [ragtime](/wiki/Ragtime "Ragtime"), [big band](/wiki/Big_band "Big band"), [swing](/wiki/Swing_music "Swing music"), Harlem [stride](/wiki/Stride_\(music\) "Stride \(music\)"), [Bounty Music](/w/index.php?title=Bounty_Music&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bounty Music \(page does not exist\)")  
Cultural origins | 1920s  
Typical instruments | [Piano](/wiki/Piano "Piano"), [saxophone](/wiki/Saxophone "Saxophone"), [clarinet](/wiki/Clarinet "Clarinet"), [trumpet](/wiki/Trumpet "Trumpet"), [double bass](/wiki/Double_bass "Double bass"), [drums](/wiki/Drum "Drum")  
Derivative forms | [Bebop](/wiki/Bebop "Bebop")  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Verbreitung_Kansas_City_Jazz.png/240px-
Verbreitung_Kansas_City_Jazz.png)](/wiki/File:Verbreitung_Kansas_City_Jazz.png)

[](/wiki/File:Verbreitung_Kansas_City_Jazz.png "Enlarge")

Towns which are popular with Kansas City jazz

**Kansas City jazz** is a style of [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") that developed in
[Kansas City](/wiki/Kansas_City_Metropolitan_Area "Kansas City Metropolitan
Area") during the 1930s and marked the transition from the structured [big
band](/wiki/Big_band "Big band") style to the [musical
improvisation](/wiki/Musical_improvisation "Musical improvisation") style of
[Bebop](/wiki/Bebop "Bebop"). The hard-swinging, bluesy transition style is
bracketed by [Count Basie](/wiki/Count_Basie "Count Basie") who in 1929 signed
with the [Bennie Moten's Kansas City Orchestra](/wiki/Bennie_Moten "Bennie
Moten") and Kansas City native [Charlie Parker](/wiki/Charlie_Parker "Charlie
Parker") who was to usher in the Bebop style in the 1940s. According to a
Kansas City website, "While [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans") was
the birthplace of jazz, America's music grew up in Kansas City".[1] Kansas
City is known as one of the most popular "cradles of jazz". Other cities
include New Orleans, [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis"), [Pittsburgh](/wiki/Pittsburgh
"Pittsburgh"), [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia"), and [New
York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[2][3]

## Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kansas_City_jazz&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

The first band from Kansas City to acquire a national reputation was the
[Coon-Sanders Original Nighthawk Orchestra](/wiki/Coon-
Sanders_Original_Nighthawk_Orchestra "Coon-Sanders Original Nighthawk
Orchestra"), a white group which broadcast nationally in the 1920s. However,
the Kansas City jazz school is identified with the black bands of the 1920s
and 1930s.

Kansas City in the 1930s was very much the crossroads of the United States
resulting in a mix of cultures. Transcontinental trips at the time whether by
plane or train often required a stop in the city. The era marked the zenith of
power of political boss [Tom Pendergast](/wiki/Tom_Pendergast "Tom
Pendergast"). Kansas City was a wide open town with liquor laws and hours
totally ignored and was called the new
[Storyville](/wiki/Storyville,_New_Orleans "Storyville, New Orleans"). Most of
the jazz musicians associated with the style were born in other places but got
caught up in the friendly musical competitions among performers that could
keep a single song being performed in variations for an entire night. Often
members of the big bands would perform at regular venues earlier in the
evening and go to the jazz clubs later to jam for the rest of the night.

[Claude Williams](/wiki/Claude_Williams_\(musician\) "Claude Williams
\(musician\)") described the scene:

    Kansas City was different from all other places because we'd be jamming all night. And [if] you come up here ... playing the wrong thing, we'd straighten you out.[4]

Clubs were scattered throughout city but the most fertile area was the [inner
city](/wiki/Inner_city "Inner city") neighborhood of [18th Street and
Vine](/wiki/18th_and_Vine_Historic_District "18th and Vine Historic
District").

Among the clubs were the Amos 'n' Andy, Boulevard Lounge, Cherry Blossom,
Chesterfield Club, Chocolate Bar, Dante's Inferno, Elk's Rest, Hawaiian
Gardens, Hell's Kitchen, the Hi Hat, the Hey Hey, Lone Star, Old Kentucky Bar-
B-Que, Paseo Ballroom, Pla-Mor Ballroom, Reno Club, Spinning Wheel, Street's
Blue Room, Subway, and Sunsetx.

## Style[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kansas_City_jazz&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Style")]

Kansas City jazz is distinguished by the following musical elements:

  * A preference for a 4 feel (walking) over the 2 beat feel found in other jazz styles of the time. As a result, Kansas city jazz had a more relaxed, fluid sound than other jazz styles.
  * Extended soloing. Fueled by the non-stop nightlife under political boss [Tom Pendergast](/wiki/Tom_Pendergast "Tom Pendergast"), Kansas City jam sessions went on well past sunrise, fostering a highly competitive atmosphere and a unique jazz culture in which the goal was to "say something" with one's instrument, rather than simply show off one's technique. It was not uncommon for one "song" to be performed for several hours, with the best musicians often soloing for dozens of choruses at a time.
  * So-called "head arrangements". The KC big bands often played by memory, composing and arranging the music collectively, rather than sight-reading as other big bands of the time did. This further contributed to the loose, spontaneous Kansas City sound.
  * A heavy blues influence, with KC songs often based around a [12-bar blues](/wiki/12-bar_blues "12-bar blues") structure, rather than the 32 bar AABA standard, although [Moten Swing](/wiki/Moten_Swing "Moten Swing") is in this AABA format.
  * One of the most recognizable characteristics of Kansas City jazz is frequent, elaborate riffing by the different sections. Riffs were often created - or even improvised - collectively, and took many forms: a) one section riffing alone, serving as the main focus of the music; b) one section riffing behind a soloist, adding excitement to the song; or c) two or more sections riffing in counterpoint, creating an exciting hard-swinging sound. The Count Basie signature tunes "[One O'Clock Jump](/wiki/One_O%27Clock_Jump "One O'Clock Jump")" and "[Jumpin' at the Woodside](/wiki/Jumpin%27_at_the_Woodside "Jumpin' at the Woodside")", for example, are simply collections of complex riffs, memorized in a head arrangement, and punctuated with solos. [Glenn Miller](/wiki/Glenn_Miller "Glenn Miller")'s famous swing anthem "[In the Mood](/wiki/In_the_Mood "In the Mood")" closely follows the Kansas City pattern of riffing sections, and is a good example of the Kansas City style after it had been exported to the rest of the world.

## Aftermath[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kansas_City_jazz&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Aftermath")]

Kansas City influence overtly transferred to the national scene in 1936 when
record producer [John H. Hammond](/wiki/John_H._Hammond "John H. Hammond")
cemented his career by discovering Kansas City talent, in the shape of Count
Basie.

Pendergast was to be convicted of income tax evasion in 1940 and the city
cracked down on the clubs effectively ending the era.

Beginning in the 1970s Kansas City has attempted to celebrate the heritage by
taking off the rough edges for family friendly environments. In the 1970s, the
city tried to create a jazz enclave in the [River Quay](/wiki/River_Quay
"River Quay") area on the Missouri River in the City Market neighborhood.
Three of the clubs were bombed during a mob war that ultimately also led to
the demise of mob influence of Las Vegas casinos that was depicted in the 1995
movie _[Casino](/wiki/Casino_\(film\) "Casino \(film\)")_.

In 1979, [Bruce Ricker](/wiki/Bruce_Ricker "Bruce Ricker") filmed _[The Last
of the Blue Devils](/wiki/The_Last_of_the_Blue_Devils "The Last of the Blue
Devils")_ , a documentary starring Basie and singer [Big Joe
Turner](/wiki/Big_Joe_Turner "Big Joe Turner"), and featuring many performers
from the original era.

In 1981 114 people died in the [Hyatt Regency walkway
collapse](/wiki/Hyatt_Regency_walkway_collapse "Hyatt Regency walkway
collapse") in an attempted recreation of the jazz scene during a [tea
dance](/wiki/Tea_dance "Tea dance").

In 1996 Kansas City native [Robert Altman](/wiki/Robert_Altman "Robert
Altman") released the film _[Kansas City](/wiki/Kansas_City_\(1996_film\)
"Kansas City \(1996 film\)")_ depicting the Kansas City jazz era.

In 1997 the [American Jazz Museum](/wiki/American_Jazz_Museum "American Jazz
Museum") opened in the [18th and Vine neighborhood](/wiki/18th_and_Vine-
Downtown_East,_Kansas_City "18th and Vine-Downtown East, Kansas City") with a
mission of celebrating Kansas City's jazz heritage.

Each year Kansas City celebrates "Jazzoo" \- a charity fundraiser dedicated to
Kansas City jazz and raising funds for the Kansas City Zoo. In 2011, Jazzoo
was one of the Nation's largest charity fundraisers, raising over $800,000.[5]
